sen.j: 徳川 家茂（とくがわ いえもち）は、江戸幕府第14代征夷大将軍。
sen.e: Iemochi TOKUGAWA is the 14th Seii Taishogun (great general who subdues the barbarians) of the Edo Shogunate.
Iemochi TOKUGAWA was the 14th Seii Taishogun (great general who subdues the barbarians) of the Edo Shogunate.
Iemochi TOKUGAWA was the 14th Seii Taishogun (great general who subdues the barbarians) of the Edo Shogunate.

sen.j: 実父は第12代将軍徳川家慶の実弟であり、第13代将軍徳川家定の従兄弟にあたる。
sen.e: His natural father is a younger brother of Ieyoshi TOKUGAWA, the 12th shogun, and a cousin of Iesada TOKUGAWA, the 13th shogun.
sen.cmt: 実弟： one's own ⇒ younger brother of の形で訳しています。
sen.e: His natural father was a younger brother of Ieyoshi TOKUGAWA, the 12th shogun, and a cousin of Iesada TOKUGAWA, the 13th shogun.
His natural father was a younger brother of Ieyoshi TOKUGAWA, the 12th shogun, and a cousin of Iesada TOKUGAWA, the 13th shogun.

sen.j: 将軍就任の前は徳川御三家紀州藩第13代藩主。
sen.e: Before becoming a shogun, he was the 13th lord of the Kishu Domain which was one of Tokugawa gosanke (three privileged branches of Tokugawa family).
Before becoming a shogun, he was the 13th lord of the Kishu Domain, one of the Tokugawa gosanke (three privileged branches of Tokugawa family).
Before becoming a shogun, he was the 13th lord of the Kishu Domain, one of the Tokugawa gosanke (three privileged branches of Tokugawa family).

sen.j: 初名は慶福（よしとみ）
sen.e: The original name is Yoshitomi.
His original name was Yoshitomi.
His original name was Yoshitomi.

sen.j: 徳川斉順（清水徳川家および紀州徳川家の当主）の長男であるが、父は家茂が生まれる前に薨去した。
sen.e: He is the first son of Nariyuki TOKUGAWA (a family head of Kiyomizu Tokugawa Family and Kishu Tokugawa Family), but his father had died before Iemochi was born.
Iemochi was the first son of Nariyuki TOKUGAWA (a family head of the Kiyomizu Tokugawa Family and the Kishu Tokugawa Family), but his father died before he was born.
sen.cmt: He > Iemochi; is > was; added "the" before "Kiyomizu" and "Kishu"; eliminated "had" before "died"; Iemochi > he;
sen.e: Iemochi was the first son of Nariyuki TOKUGAWA (a family head of the Shimizu Tokugawa Family and the Kishu Tokugawa Family), but his father died before he was born.

sen.j: 祖父は徳川家斉、祖母は妙操院。
sen.e: His grandfather is Ienari TOKUGAWA, and his grandmother is Myosoin.
His grandfather was Ienari TOKUGAWA and his grandmother was Myosoin.
His grandfather was Ienari TOKUGAWA and his grandmother was Myosoin.

sen.j: 正室は孝明天皇の妹・和宮親子内親王（静観院宮）。
sen.e: His seishitsu (legal wife) is Imperial Princess Kazunomiya Chikako (Seikan ingu [imperial lady]), a younger sister of the Emperor Komei.
His seishitsu (legal wife) was Imperial Princess Kazunomiya Chikako (Seikan ingu [imperial lady]), a younger sister of Emperor Komei.
His seishitsu (legal wife) was Imperial Princess Kazunomiya Chikako (Seikan ingu [imperial lady]), a younger sister of Emperor Komei.

sen.j: 徳川氏中、世継ぎのいなかった第13代将軍・徳川家定に最も近い血筋の人物であるとして、譜代筆頭の井伊直弼ら南紀派の支持を受けて13歳で第14代将軍となる。
sen.e: As a person who is related to more closely to Iesada TOKUGAWA, the 13th shogun who didn't have an heir, he was supported by Naosuke II, fudai hitto, and other people in Nanki group (group supporting Yoshitomi from the Kishu-Tokugawa family) and became the 14th shogun at the age of 13.

As the closest relative to Iesada TOKUGAWA, the 13th shogun who did not have an heir, Iemochi became the 14th shogun at the age of thirteen, supported by Naosuke II, Fudai Hitto and others in the Nanki group (the group that supported Yoshitomi from the Kishu-Tokugawa family).
sen.cmt: capitalized "Fudai Hitto"; 13 > thirteen; rearranged sentence and fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: As the closest relative to Iesada TOKUGAWA, the 13th shogun who did not have an heir, Iemochi became the 14th shogun at the age of thirteen, supported by Naosuke II, Fudai Hitto and others in the Nanki group (the group that supported Yoshitomi from the Kishu-Tokugawa family).

sen.j: 血筋だけでなく英明な風格を備えており、勝海舟をはじめ幕臣からの信望厚く、忠誠を集めたと言われている。
sen.e: He had not only the genealogy but also discerning attitude, and it has been said that he had great prestige among shogun's retainers such as Kaishu KATSU and they gave their loyalty to him.
Not only did he have the genealogy, but a discerning attitude as well, and it is said that he held great prestige among the shogunal retainers, such as Kaishu KATSU, who gave their loyalty to him.
sen.cmt: shogun's > shogunal; fixed to read more naturally
sen.e: Not only did he have the genealogy, but a discerning attitude as well, and it is said that he held great prestige among the shogunal retainers, such as Kaishu KATSU, who gave their loyalty to him.

sen.j: 弘化3年（1846年）閏5月24日、紀州藩第11代藩主・徳川斉順の長男として江戸の紀州江戸藩邸（現：東京都港区 (東京都)）で生まれる。
sen.e: He was born on May 24, 1846 as the first son of Nariyuki TOKUGAWA, the 11th lord of Kishu Domain, in Kishu edohantei (residence maintained by a daimyo in Edo) in Edo (current Minato Ward, Tokyo [Tokyo]).

Iemochi was born on May 24, 1846 as the first son of Nariyuki TOKUGAWA, the 11th lord of the Kishu Domain in Kishu edohantei (residence maintained by a daimyo in Edo) in Edo (current Minato Ward, Tokyo).
sen.cmt: He > Iemochi; added "the" before "Kishu"; eliminated comma after "Domain"; eliminated [Tokyo]
sen.e: Iemochi was born on May 24, 1846 as the first son of Nariyuki TOKUGAWA, the 11th lord of the Kishu Domain in Kishu edohantei (residence maintained by a daimyo in Edo) in Edo (current Minato Ward, Tokyo).

sen.j: 幼名は菊千代。
sen.e: His childhood name is Kikuchiyo.
His childhood name was Kikuchiyo.
His childhood name was Kikuchiyo.

sen.j: 嘉永2年（1849年）に叔父で第12代藩主である徳川斉彊が死去したため、その養子縁組として家督を4歳で継ぎ、第13代藩主となった。
sen.e: Since Narikatsu TOKUGAWA, his uncle and the 12th lord of domain, died in 1849, he was adopted to take over the family estate when he was 4 and became the 13th lord of the domain.

Due to the passing of his uncle, the 12th lord of the domain named Narikatsu TOKUGAWA, Iemochi was adopted to take over the family estate when he was four years old and became the 13th lord of the domain in 1849.
sen.cmt: moved year to the end of the sentence since I could not get it to sound natural anywhere else; rearranged sentence and fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: Due to the passing of his uncle, the 12th lord of the domain named Narikatsu TOKUGAWA, Iemochi was adopted to take over the family estate when he was four years old and became the 13th lord of the domain in 1849.

sen.j: 安政5年（1858年）、一橋派との抗争の末に勝利し、直後に第13代将軍・徳川家定も死去したために第14代将軍となった。
sen.e: He beat the Hitotsubashi family in a struggle in 1858 and became the 14th shogun since Iesada TOKUGAWA, the 13th shogun, also died soon after the struggle.
sen.cmt: ”直後に”のところを、”抗争の直後に”と補いました。
sen.e: He defeated the Hitotsubashi family in a struggle in 1858, then became the 14th shogun due to the death of the 13th shogun, Iesada TOKUGAWA, soon after the struggle.
sen.cmt: beat > defeated; died > death of - fixed to read more naturally
sen.e: He defeated the Hitotsubashi family in a struggle in 1858, then became the 14th shogun due to the death of the 13th shogun, Iesada TOKUGAWA, soon after the struggle.

sen.j: 家茂はこの時13歳という若年であったが、第13代将軍・徳川家定の従兄弟に当たり前将軍の最近親ということから、血縁を徳川初代の徳川家康まで遡らなくてはならない慶喜を抑えて将軍に就任したのである。
sen.e: Though Iemochi was just 13 then, since he was a cousin of Iesada TOKUGAWA, the 13th shogun, and related to the former shogun more closely, he became shogun putting out Yoshinobu whose blood relationship ran back to Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, the first shogun of Tokugawa family.

Although Iemochi was only thirteen at the time he became shogun, since he was a cousin of the 13th shogun Iesada TOKUGAWA and more closely related to the former shogun, he was chosen even over Yoshinobu whose blood relationship ran back to Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, the first shogun of Tokugawa family.
sen.cmt: was just 13 then > was only thirteen at the time; rearranged sentence and fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: Although Iemochi was only thirteen at the time he became shogun, since he was a cousin of the 13th shogun Iesada TOKUGAWA and more closely related to the former shogun, he was chosen even over Yoshinobu whose blood relationship ran back to Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, the first shogun of Tokugawa family.

sen.j: とはいえ、文久2年（1862年）までは徳川慶頼が、その後は徳川慶喜が「将軍後見職」に就いていたため、その権力は抑制されていた。
sen.e: However, since Yoshiyori TOKUGAWA served as Shogun-kokenshoku until 1862 and Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA did after that, his authority had been restrained.
Iemochi's authority was inhibited, however, due to Yoshiyori TOKUGAWA serving as Shogun-kokenshoku until 1862, followed by Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA.
sen.cmt: rearranged sentence and fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: Iemochi's authority was inhibited, however, due to Yoshiyori TOKUGAWA serving as Shogun-kokenshoku until 1862, followed by Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA.

sen.j: 文久2年（1862年）に公武合体策の一環として和宮親子内親王と結婚。
sen.e: In 1862, he got married to Imperial Princess Kazunomiya Chikako as a part of the union of the imperial Court and the Shogunate.
In 1862, Iemochi was married to Imperial Princess Kazunomiya Chikako as a part of a union of the Imperial Court and the Shogunate.
sen.cmt: he > Iemochi; the union > a union; capitalized "Imperial";
sen.e: In 1862, Iemochi was married to Imperial Princess Kazunomiya Chikako as a part of a union of the Imperial Court and the Shogunate.

sen.j: 政略結婚ではあるが、和宮に対してたびたび贈り物をするなど細やかな気配りをし、2人の関係は良好であった。
sen.e: Though it was a marriage for political reason, he took a good care of her like presenting gifts to Kazunomiya often, and they were in a good relationship.
Although their marriage was political, they had a good relationship with him showing many kindnesses to her such as presenting her with gifts on many occasions.
sen.cmt: rearranged sentence, fixed grammar and word selection to read more naturally
sen.e: Although their marriage was political, they had a good relationship with him showing many kindnesses to her such as presenting her with gifts on many occasions.

sen.j: 徳川家歴代の将軍と正室の中で最も夫婦仲が良かったのは家茂・和宮といわれたほどである。
sen.e: It was said that out of successive husbands and wives in the Tokugawa family, Iemochi and Kazunomiya were most happily married.
It was said that out of successive husbands and wives in the Tokugawa family, Iemochi and Kazunomiya were the most happily married.
It was said that out of successive husbands and wives in the Tokugawa family, Iemochi and Kazunomiya were the most happily married.

sen.j: 文久3年（1863年）には将軍としては229年振りとなる上洛を果たし、義兄に当たる孝明天皇に攘夷を誓った。
sen.e: In 1863, he went to the capital (Kyoto) as Shogun for the first time in 229 years and pledged expulsion of foreigners to the Emperor Komei, his brother in law.
In 1863, Iemochi went to the capital (Kyoto) as Shogun, something which had not occurred for 229 years, and made a pledge to Emperor Komei, his brother-in-law, to expel foreigners from Japan.
sen.cmt: he > Iemochi; for the first time in 229 years > something which had not occurred for 229 years; added "from Japan"; rearranged sentence and fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: In 1863, Iemochi went to the capital (Kyoto) as Shogun, something which had not occurred for 229 years, and made a pledge to Emperor Komei, his brother-in-law, to expel foreigners from Japan.

sen.j: 慶応元年（1865年）、兵庫開港を決定した老中・阿部正外らが朝廷によって処罰されると、自ら将軍職の辞意を朝廷に上申している。
sen.e: When Masato ABE, a roju (member of shogun's council of elders), and other people who decided to open Hyogo port were brought to justice by Chotei (Imperial Court), he offered his resignation from shogunate by himself to Chotei.

In 1865, when a roju (a member of the shogun's council of elders) named Masato ABE and a group his supporters were punished by the Chotei (Imperial Court) for making the decision to open the port in Hyogo, Iemochi offered his resignation from the shogunate to the Chotei on his own.
sen.cmt: added "In 1865"; rearranged sentence and fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: In 1865, when a roju (a member of the shogun's council of elders) named Masato ABE and a group his supporters were punished by the Chotei (Imperial Court) for making the decision to open the port in Hyogo, Iemochi offered his resignation from the shogunate to the Chotei on his own.

sen.j: このとき孝明天皇は大いに驚き慌てて辞意を取り下げさせ、その後の幕府人事への干渉をしないと約束したという。
sen.e: It is said that the Emperor Komei was very surprised at this time, made him withdraw his offer, and promised that he wouldn't intervene in future personnel affairs in bakufu.

Purportedly, Emperor Komei was very surprised by this, making Iemochi withdraw from his intention to resign and promised from then on not to intervene in the affairs of the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
sen.cmt: It is said > Purportedly,; withdraw his offer > withdraw from his intention to resign; added description for bakufu; fixed grammar
sen.e: Purportedly, Emperor Komei was very surprised by this, making Iemochi withdraw from his intention to resign and promised from then on not to intervene in the affairs of the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

sen.j: 慶応2年（1866年）、家茂は第2次長州征伐の途上大坂城で病に倒れた。
sen.e: In 1866, Iemochi suffered from a disease in Osaka Castle on the way to the 2nd conquest of Choshu.
In 1866, Iemochi suffered from a disease in Osaka Castle during the second conquest of Choshu.
sen.cmt: on the way to > during; 2nd > second;
sen.e: In 1866, Iemochi suffered from a disease in Osaka Castle during the second conquest of Choshu.

sen.j: この知らせを聞いた孝明天皇は、典薬寮の医師である高階経由と福井貞憲の2人を大坂へ派遣し、その治療に当たらせた。
sen.e: When the Emperor Komei was informed of this, he dispatched two doctors from Tenyakuryo (the Bureau of Medicine), 高階経由 and Sadanori FUKUI, to Osaka to give him medical treatment.
sen.cmt: 高階経由: 読み方不明
sen.e: When Emperor Komei was informed of this, he dispatched two doctors from the Tenyakuryo (Bureau of Medicine) named 高階経由 and Sadanori FUKUI to Osaka to give Iemochi medical treatment.
sen.cmt: eliminated "the" before "Emperor"; added "the" before "Tenyakuryo"; eliminated "the" before "Bureau"; eliminated commas; added "named"; him > Iemochi
sen.e: When Emperor Komei was informed of this, he dispatched two doctors from the Tenyakuryo (Bureau of Medicine) named Tsuneyoshi TAKASHINA and Sadanori FUKUI to Osaka to give Iemochi medical treatment.
sen.cmt: 高階経由の読みTsuneyoshi TAKASHINAを入れました。

sen.j: 江戸城からは、天璋院や和宮親子内親王の侍医として留守をまもっていた大膳亮弘玄院、多紀養春院（多紀安琢）、遠田澄庵、高島祐庵、浅田宗伯らが大坂へ急派された。
sen.e: From Edo Castle, Daizen no suke (the title of a person who was in charge of meals in the court) Kogen in, Taki Yoshun in (Antaku TAKI), Choan TODA, Yuan TAKASHIMA, Sohaku ASADA, etc., who were serving for Tenshoin and Imperial Princess Kazunomiya Chikako as jii (court physician) while holding the fort were urgently dispatched to Osaka.

Among others, Daizen no suke (title of the person in charge of meals in the court) Kogen-in, Taki Yoshun-in (Antaku TAKI), Choan TODA, Yuan TAKASHIMA and Sohaku ASADA, all who served the Tenshoin and Imperial Princess Kazunomiya Chikako as court physicians who normally stayed in the castle at all times, were urgently dispatched to Osaka from Edo Castle.
sen.cmt: changed "while holding the fort" to "who normally stayed in the castle at all times" for "留守をまもっていた"; changed "etc" to "Among others" and put at the beginning; eliminated "the" before "title"; a person > the person; added hyphen in "Kogen-in" and "Yoshun-in"; added "all" before "who served"; serving > served; eliminated "jii" and the parenthesis around "court physician"; moved "from Edo Castle" to the end of the sentence; fixed other grammar
sen.e: Among others, Daizen no suke (title of the person in charge of meals in the court) Kogen-in, Taki Yoshun-in (Antaku TAKI), Choan TODA, Yuan TAKASHIMA and Sohaku ASADA, all who served the Tenshoin and Imperial Princess Kazunomiya Chikako as court physicians who normally stayed in the castle at all times, were urgently dispatched to Osaka from Edo Castle.

sen.j: しかしその甲斐なく、家茂は同年7月20日に大坂城にて薨去した。
sen.e: Despite the efforts, Iemochi died on July 20 of the same year in Osaka Castle.
Despite the efforts, Iemochi died on July 20 of the same year in Osaka Castle.
Despite the efforts, Iemochi died on July 20 of the same year in Osaka Castle.

sen.j: 享年21（満20歳没）。
sen.e: Age at death: 21 (died after his 20th birthday)
He died at the age of twenty-one (death after his twentieth birthday).
He died at the age of twenty-one (death after his twentieth birthday).

sen.j: 将軍家茂は英明さと真摯さで幕臣達に慕われており、勝海舟などは「家茂さまの御薨去をもって徳川幕府は滅んだ」と嘆息したと伝えられる。
sen.e: Shogun Iemochi were beloved of shogun's retainers for his discerning and serious attitude, and it is said that Kaishu KATSU moaned saying 'the Tokugawa shogunate died down because of his death.'
Shogun Iemochi was loved by his retainers for his discerning and serious attitude, and it is said that in his grief, Kaishu KATSU said 'The Tokugawa shogunate is ruined because of his death.'
sen.cmt: died down > 滅ぶ→ruined; fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: Shogun Iemochi was loved by his retainers for his discerning and serious attitude, and it is said that in his grief, Kaishu KATSU said 'The Tokugawa shogunate is ruined because of his death.'

tit.cmt: capitalized "Nomination" and "Successor" since this is a section

sen.j: 家茂は死に際し、徳川家達（田安家）を次期徳川家の当主・将軍として指名し、遺言とした。
sen.e: At the time of his death, Iemochi left a will designating Iesato TOKUGAWA (the Tayasu family) as the next family head ・ shogun of the Tokugawa family.
At the time of his death, Iemochi left a will designating Iesato TOKUGAWA (the Tayasu family) as the next family head and shogun of the Tokugawa family.
At the time of his death, Iemochi left a will designating Iesato TOKUGAWA (the Tayasu family) as the next family head and shogun of the Tokugawa family.

sen.j: 家茂は、慶喜は優秀ではあるが、それゆえに自策に溺れる可能性が高いのに対し、亀之助は幼少であるがゆえに幕閣の合議により最上の幕府の運営が出来ると考えていたとされている。
sen.e: It's been said that Iemochi thought Yoshinobu was smart but he could attach to his own idea because of his smartness, however, Kamenosuke was young and this would make the best management of bakufu possible through agreement by the cabinet officials of the Shogunate.

Iemochi allegedly thought that although Yoshinobu was smart, this made it highly possible that he would end up outsmarting himself, while Kamenosuke on the other hand, was young having him as shogun would create the best management of the bakufu possible through agreement of the cabinet officials of the Shogunate.

Iemochi allegedly thought that although Yoshinobu was smart, this made it highly possible that he would end up outsmarting himself, while Kamenosuke on the other hand, was young having him as shogun would create the best management of the bakufu possible through agreement of the cabinet officials of the Shogunate.

sen.j: また亀之助は、血統の上でも自分や義父である徳川家定と最近親の徳川家の家族であり、初代徳川家康まで遡らなければ、歴代将軍達と血が繋がらないような慶喜よりも旗本および譜代大名の忠誠心を引き出せると考えていたようである。
sen.e: In addition, it seems that he thought loyalty of bakufu hatamoto (direct retainers of the bakufu, which is a form of Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and fudai daimyo (a daimyo in hereditary vassal to the Tokugawa family) could be more generated with Kamenosuke, who was a family of Tokugawa and related to himself and Iesada TOKUGAWA, his father in law, most closely than with Yoshinobu whose blood relationship had to run back to the first Shogun, Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, to relate to the successive shoguns.

It seems that Iemochi thought that more loyalty could be generated from the bakufu hatamoto (direct retainers of the shogun) and fudai daimyo (daimyo and hereditary vassals to the Tokugawa family) with Kamenosuke, who was related to himself and his father-in-law Iesada TOKUGAWA, than Yoshinobu, whose blood relationship did not seem to be closely tied to successive shoguns aside from his relation to the first Shogun, Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.
sen.cmt: eliminated "In addition"; eliminated "which is a form of Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun" since it this description is given above; fixed to read more naturally
sen.e: It seems that Iemochi thought that more loyalty could be generated from the bakufu hatamoto (direct retainers of the shogun) and fudai daimyo (daimyo and hereditary vassals to the Tokugawa family) with Kamenosuke, who was related to himself and his father-in-law Iesada TOKUGAWA, than Yoshinobu, whose blood relationship did not seem to be closely tied to successive shoguns aside from his relation to the first Shogun, Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.

sen.j: 家茂はわずか20年の生涯であったが、幕末の動乱期の中をその若さで潜り抜けていることは高く評価されている。
sen.e: Though Iemochi lived only for 20 years, it has been highly valued that he coped with unquiet days in the end of Edo Period.
Although Iemochi only lived for twenty years, he was highly valued for coping with the tumultuous time during the end of Edo Period.
sen.cmt: Though > Although; lived only > only lived; 20 > twenty; unquiet > tumultuous; days > time; in > during; fixed grammar
sen.e: Although Iemochi only lived for twenty years, he was highly valued for coping with the tumultuous time during the end of Edo Period.

sen.j: 勝海舟からは、「若さゆえに時代に翻弄されたが、もう少し長く生きていれば、英邁な君主として名を残したかもしれない。武勇にも優れていた人物であった」と評価されている。
sen.e: Kaishu KATSU valued him saying 'though he was at the mercy of the period because of his youth, if he lived a little bit longer, he might earn his place in history as a great monarch, and he also had excellent military prowess.'

Kaishu KATSU praised Iemochi saying, 'Though he was at the mercy of the period because of his youth, if he had lived a little bit longer, he might have earned his place in history as a great monarch in addition to his excellent military prowess.'
sen.cmt: valued > praised; added comma after "saying"; capitalized "Though"; eliminated comma after "monarch" changing "and" to "in addition to his"; fixed grammar
sen.e: Kaishu KATSU praised Iemochi saying, 'Though he was at the mercy of the period because of his youth, if he had lived a little bit longer, he might have earned his place in history as a great monarch in addition to his excellent military prowess.'

sen.j: また、幕臣からも信望が厚かったと言われ、家臣や女性や動物たちに至るまで非常に優しい態度で接する一方、剛毅な一面を持つ人柄が明治以後に旧幕臣たちなどから様々な逸話で伝えられている。
sen.e: In addition, it is said that he had great prestige among shogun's retainers, and various anecdotes told by former shogun's retainers in late Meiji Period show that he was mensch while he was very kind to everyone from vassal and women to animals.

It is also said that he held great prestige among the shogunal retainers, and various anecdotes told by former retainers from the late Meiji Period tell that he had fortitude and firmness of character, yet he was very kind to everyone, from vassals and women to animals.
sen.cmt: eliminated "In addition" and added "also" after "It is"; shogun's > shogunal; fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: It is also said that he held great prestige among the shogunal retainers, and various anecdotes told by former retainers from the late Meiji Period tell that he had fortitude and firmness of character, yet he was very kind to everyone, from vassals and women to animals.

sen.j: 羊羹、氷砂糖、金平糖、カステラ、最中、三色菓子など甘いものを好んだ。
sen.e: He liked sweets such as yokan (a bar of sweetened and jellied bean paste), rock candy, compeito (confetti), castella sponge cake, monaka (a wafer cake filled with bean jam), three-color sweets, etc.

Iemochi liked sweets, such as yokan (a bar of sweetened and jellied bean paste), rock candy, compeito (confetti), castella sponge cake, monaka (a wafer cake filled with bean jam) and three-color sweets.
sen.cmt: He > Iemochi; added comma after "sweets"; changed the comma after the last parenthesis to an "and"; eliminated "etc." since "such as" is used at the beginning of the sentence
sen.e: Iemochi liked sweets, such as yokan (a bar of sweetened and jellied bean paste), rock candy, compeito (confetti), castella sponge cake, monaka (a wafer cake filled with bean jam) and three-color sweets.

sen.j: う蝕や脚気の原因はこれらの食べすぎだと思われる。
sen.e: It seems taking those sweets too much caused dental caries and beriberi.
It is believed that the cause of his tooth decay and beriberi (deficiency of vitamin B1) was due to a overconsumption of these sweets.
sen.cmt: dental caries > tooth decay; added description for "beriberi"; fixed to read more naturally
sen.e: It is believed that the cause of his tooth decay and beriberi (deficiency of vitamin B1) was due to a overconsumption of these sweets.

sen.j: 四肢骨からの推算で身長は156.6cmである。
sen.e: He is 156.6 cm tall by estimation from his bones of the extremities.
He is estimated to have been 156.6 cm tall, judging by the length of the bones of his extremities.
He is estimated to have been 156.6 cm tall, judging by the length of the bones of his extremities.

sen.j: 遺骨から面長で極めて鼻が高く、歯は反り歯であったことが分かっている。
sen.e: His cremains tell that he had a narrow face, very long nose, and warped teeth.
His remains tell that he had a narrow face, a very long nose and warped teeth.
sen.cmt: cremains > remains; added "a" beforey "very"; eliminated comma after "nose";
sen.e: His remains tell that he had a narrow face, a very long nose and warped teeth.

sen.j: 肖像画の顔はそうした特長をよく表している。
sen.e: His portrait expresses such characteristics very well.
His portrait expresses these characteristics very well.
His portrait expresses these characteristics very well.

sen.j: 慶喜が見舞いに来た際には普通に会話をしたと言われる。
sen.e: It is said that he talked as usual when Yoshinobu visited him.
It is said that he spoke in a normal manner when Yoshinobu visited him.
sen.cmt: talked as usual > spoke in a normal manner;
sen.e: It is said that he spoke in a normal manner when Yoshinobu visited him.

sen.j: 『増上寺徳川将軍家墓とその遺品・遺体』によると、家茂の血液型はA型である。
sen.e: According to "The Tokugawa Shogun family's tombs in Zojo-ji Temple and their articles left by the deceased ・ corpse", Iemochi's blood type is A.
According to "The Tokugawa Shogun family's tombs in Zojo-ji Temple and the remains and articles left by the deceased," Iemochi's blood type was A.
sen.cmt: their remains > the remains; eliminated "・corpse" and changed to "remains"; moved comma to inside parenthesis; is > was
sen.e: According to "The Tokugawa Shogun family's tombs in Zojo-ji Temple and the remains and articles left by the deceased," Iemochi's blood type was A.

sen.j: 昭和33年（1958年）から35年（1960年）に増上寺の徳川将軍家墓地改葬の際に徳川家の人々の遺骨の調査を行った鈴木尚の著書・『骨は語る 徳川将軍・大名家の人びと』によれば、家茂は死亡した時点ではさかやきを剃っておらず、若々しく豊富な髪の持ち主であったという。
sen.e: According to "Cremains Talk The Tokugawa Shogun Family ・ The Daimyo Family" by Hisashi SUZUKI who researched cremains of Tokugawa family at the reburial of the Tokugawa Shogun family grave in Zojo-ji Temple from 1958 to 1960, when Iemochi died, he didn't get his Sakayaki shaved and he looked young with thick hair.

According to "Bones Talk: The Tokugawa Shogun Family/The Daimyo Family" by Hisashi SUZUKI, who carried out research on the remains at the reburial of the Tokugawa Shogun family grave in Zojo-ji Temple between 1958 and 1960, when Iemochi died, he had not shaved his head and put his hair in a topknot, and he looked young with thick hair.
sen.cmt: Cremains > Bones (骨); added colon after "Talk"; ・>/; changed "didn't get his Sakayaki shaved" to "had not shaved his head and put his hair in a topknot"; fixed to read more naturally
sen.e: According to "Bones Talk: The Tokugawa Shogun Family/The Daimyo Family" by Hisashi SUZUKI, who carried out research on the remains at the reburial of the Tokugawa Shogun family grave in Zojo-ji Temple between 1958 and 1960, when Iemochi died, he had not shaved his head and put his hair in a topknot, and he looked young with thick hair.

sen.j: また家茂の歯の虫歯の度合いは酷く、残存する31本の歯の内30本が虫歯にかかっていた。
sen.e: In addition, he had so bad teeth that 30 of the existing 31 teeth were bad ones.
His teeth were so badly rotten that thirty of his thirty-one teeth had cavities.
sen.cmt: eliminated "In addition"; fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: His teeth were so badly rotten that thirty of his thirty-one teeth had cavities.

sen.j: 記録などから総合するに、家茂はもともと歯のエナメル質が極端に薄い体質であったうえ、大の甘党でもあった。
sen.e: By piecing together records, Iemochi's teeth enamel was extremely thin by nature and he also loved sweets very much.
By piecing together records, Iemochi's teeth enamel was found to be naturally extremely thin, made worse by his love for sweets.
By piecing together records, Iemochi's teeth enamel was found to be naturally extremely thin, made worse by his love for sweets.

sen.j: その虫歯が家茂の体力を弱め、脚気衝心、さらには医師間の診断内容の相違（高階ら漢方の典医は脚気との診断を下したが、西洋医の幕府奥医師たちはこれをリウマチだとして譲らなかった）も加わり、家茂の命を奪ったのではないか、と指摘している。
sen.e: It is suggested that heart failure from beriberi and, furthermore, conflicts in diagnosis between doctors (traditional Chinese medicine doctors such as Takashina diagnosed him as beriberi but western medical doctors such as those from bakufu insisted his case as rheumatism) as well as the bad teeth weakening his stamina claimed his life.

It is suggested that what claimed his life, along with his bad teeth that weakened his stamina and heart failure from beriberi, were the conflicts in diagnosis between doctors (traditional Chinese medicine doctors, such as Takashina, diagnosed him with beriberi but western medical doctors, such as those from the bakufu, insisted he had rheumatism).
sen.cmt: added "the" before "bakufu"; rearranged sentence and fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: It is suggested that what claimed his life, along with his bad teeth that weakened his stamina and heart failure from beriberi, were the conflicts in diagnosis between doctors (traditional Chinese medicine doctors, such as Takashina, diagnosed him with beriberi but western medical doctors, such as those from the bakufu, insisted he had rheumatism).

sen.j: また同書に寄れば、家茂の物とは明らかに違う女性の物らしき長髪が棺の中に同封されていたが、和宮の髪とは髪質が異なる点、棺の封は大坂で為された物と推測される。
sen.e: Furthermore, according to the book, though long hair of a woman, which was completely different from Iemochi's hair, was included in the casket, since the hair type was different from that of Kazunomiya, it is assumed that the casket was sealed in Osaka.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: According to the book, although the long hair of a woman completely different from Iemochi's hair was included in the casket, since the hair type was different from that of Kazunomiya, it is assumed that the casket was sealed in Osaka.
sen.cmt: eliminated "Furthermore"; though > although; eliminated comma after "woman"; eliminated "which was"; eliminated comma after "Iemochi's hair";
sen.e: According to the book, although the long hair of a woman completely different from Iemochi's hair was included in the casket, since the hair type was different from that of Kazunomiya, it is assumed that the casket was sealed in Osaka.

sen.j: しかし、当時江戸在住だった和宮が髪を入れることは不可能だった点から、この髪の持ち主は家茂に同行し、家茂に近かった女性-つまり側室-のものではないか、と推測されている。
sen.e: However, since it was impossible for Kazunomiya who lived in Edo at that time to put her hair in, it is assumed that the hair belonged to a woman who accompanied Iemochi and were close to him, i.e. his concubine.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Due to the fact that it was impossible for Kazunomiya to have put her hair in the casket since she had been living in Edo at the time, it is assumed that the hair belonged to a woman, perhaps a concubine, who accompanied Iemochi and was close to him.
sen.cmt: eliminated "However"; since > Due to the fact that; fixed to read more naturally
sen.e: Due to the fact that it was impossible for Kazunomiya to have put her hair in the casket since she had been living in Edo at the time, it is assumed that the hair belonged to a woman, perhaps a concubine, who accompanied Iemochi and was close to him.

sen.j: また墓地改葬の際に、和宮の墓の中から家茂と思われる男性の肖像写真が発見された。
sen.e: In addition, at the reburial of the grave, a portrait of a man, who seems to be Iemochi, was found from Kazunomiya's grave.
During the reburial of the Tokugawa Shogun family, a photograph of a man who seems to be Iemochi was found in Kazunomiya's grave.
sen.cmt: eliminated "In addition"; changed the first "grave" to "Tokugawa Shogun family" to avoid redundency of the word; portrait > photograph; fixed grammar
sen.e: During the reburial of the Tokugawa Shogun family, a photograph of a man who seems to be Iemochi was found in Kazunomiya's grave.

sen.j: これまで家茂は義兄の孝明天皇に倣い写真は撮影していなかったと思われていた。
sen.e: In the past, it has been thought that Iemochi followed the Emperor Komei, his brother in law, and didn't get his photos taken.
Until that time, it was believed that Iemochi followed Emperor Komei, his brother in law, in not having his photo taken.
sen.cmt: In the past > Until that time; it has been though > it was believed; eliminated "the" before "Emperor"; and didn't get his photos taken > in not having his photo taken
sen.e: Until that time, it was believed that Iemochi followed Emperor Komei, his brother in law, in not having his photo taken.

sen.j: この写真は死の直前に大坂で撮影され、江戸にいる和宮に贈られたものとみられる。
sen.e: It seems that photo was taken in Osaka Castle right before his death and sent to Kazunomiya who was in Edo.
The photo seems to have been taken in Osaka Castle right before his death and then sent to Kazunomiya in Edo.
sen.cmt: It seems that photo was taken > The photo seems to have been taken; fixed grammar
sen.e: The photo seems to have been taken in Osaka Castle right before his death and then sent to Kazunomiya in Edo.

sen.j: 発見の翌日に写真を検証しようとすると日光のためか画像は失われており、そこにはガラス板があるのみだった。
sen.e: When they tried to examine the photo on the day after the discovery, the image was lost may be because of sunlight, and there was nothing but a glass plate.
When an attempt was made to examine the photo the day after the discovery, the image was lost, likely due to getting hit by sunlight, and there was nothing but a glass plate.
sen.cmt: fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: When an attempt was made to examine the photo the day after the discovery, the image was lost, likely due to getting hit by sunlight, and there was nothing but a glass plate.

sen.j: 幼少の頃は池の魚や籠の鳥を可愛がるのを楽しみとしていた。
sen.e: In his childhood, he enjoyed taking care of fish in a pond and cage birds.
In his childhood, Iemochi enjoyed taking care of fish in a pond and caged birds.
sen.cmt: changed "he" to "Iemochi" since this is a new section; cage > caged
sen.e: In his childhood, Iemochi enjoyed taking care of fish in a pond and caged birds.

sen.j: しかし13歳の時に将軍として元服すると、それらの楽しみを捨てて文武両道を修めるように努めた。
sen.e: However, when he reached the manhood as a shogun at the age of 13, he gave up those pleasure and made an effort to acquire both the literary and military arts.
However, when he reached manhood as the shogun at the age of thirteen, he gave up these pleasures and made an effort to acquire both the literary and military arts.
sen.cmt: eliminated "the" before "mandhood"; added "the" before "shogun"; 13 > thirteen; those > these;
sen.e: However, when he reached manhood as the shogun at the age of thirteen, he gave up these pleasures and made an effort to acquire both the literary and military arts.

sen.j: 病弱な体なのにささやかな楽しみすら捨て、良い将軍であろうと心がけていた姿は幕臣たちを当時も没後も感激させたという。
sen.e: Though he was sickly, he gave up the trivial pleasure and tried to be a good shogun, and it is said that the attitude made shogun's retainers feel impressed then and after his death.

Even though he had a weak constitution, he gave up trivial pleasures and set his heart on being a good shogun, and it is said that the shogunal retainers were impressed with his attitude before and even after his death.
sen.cmt: Though he was sickly > Even though he had a weak constitution; fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: Even though he had a weak constitution, he gave up trivial pleasures and set his heart on being a good shogun, and it is said that the shogunal retainers were impressed with his attitude before and even after his death.

sen.j: 書の達人として知られていた幕臣戸川安清は70歳を過ぎた老人ながら、推されて家茂の習字の先生を務めていた。
sen.e: Yasukiyo TOGAWA, who was a shogun's retainer and known as a master of calligraphy, was an old man over 70 but he served for Iemochi as a teacher of calligraphy since he was recommended.
Yasukiyo TOGAWA, a shogunal retainer and known master of calligraphy, was an old man over seventy years old but served Iemochi as a recommended teacher of calligraphy.
sen.cmt: shogun's > shogunal; a teacher of calligraphy since he was recommended > a recommended teacher of calligraphy; fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: Yasukiyo TOGAWA, a shogunal retainer and known master of calligraphy, was an old man over seventy years old but served Iemochi as a recommended teacher of calligraphy.

sen.j: ある時家茂に教えていた最中に、突然家茂が安清の頭の上から墨を摺るための水をかけ手を打って笑い、「あとは明日にしよう」と言ってその場を出て行ってしまった。
sen.e: One day, while he was teaching Iemochi, Iemochi suddenly poured water used for Chinese ink over Yasukiyo's head, clapped his hands while laughing and went out of the place saying 'we will do that tomorrow'.

One time while he was giving a lesson, Iemochi suddenly poured water used for Chinese ink over Yasukiyo's head, laughed while he clapped his hands and left the lesson saying, 'Let's do the rest tomorrow.'
sen.cmt: changed translation of the quote to sound more naturally; fixed grammar
sen.e: One time while he was giving a lesson, Iemochi suddenly poured water used for Chinese ink over Yasukiyo's head, laughed while he clapped his hands and left the lesson saying, 'Let's do the rest tomorrow.'

sen.j: 同席していた側近たちがいつもの家茂にも似ぬことをすると嘆いていると、当の安清が泣いていた。
sen.e: When close associates present lamented his unusual behavior, Yasukiyo himself was crying.
While the close associates present at the time were lamenting over Iemochi's unusual behavior, Yasukiyo cried.
While the close associates present at the time were lamenting over Iemochi's unusual behavior, Yasukiyo cried.

sen.j: 家茂の振る舞いを情けなく思ってのことかと尋ねると、実は老齢のため、ふとしたはずみで失禁してしまったと安清は言った。
sen.e: When they asked him if he was crying over Iemochi's bad behavior, he answered that he accidentally had incontinence due to his age.
When they asked him if he was crying over Iemochi's bad behavior, he answered that he had a sudden bout of incontinence due to his age.
sen.cmt: he accidentally had incontinence > he had a sudden bout of incontinence
sen.e: When they asked him if he was crying over Iemochi's bad behavior, he answered that he had a sudden bout of incontinence due to his age.

sen.j: 当時の習慣として将軍に教えている真っ最中に尿を漏らしたとなると厳罰は免れないので、それを察した家茂は水をかけるいたずらをすることでその失敗を隠し、「明日も出仕するように」と発言することで不問に処することを表明したのである。
sen.e: As customs in those days, it was inevitable to be severely punished if you had incontinence while teaching a shogun, therefore, Iemochi sensed it and hid the accident by going into mischief pouring water over him and expressed that he wouldn't blame him by saying 'you have to attend at the court tomorrow as well.'

Since it was a custom of those days to invariably and severely punish someone having incontinence while teaching a shogun, Iemochi realized this and hid the accident by mischievously pouring water on Yasukiyo, expressing that he would overlook the incident by saying, 'You have to attend at the court tomorrow as well.'
sen.cmt: rearranged sentence and fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: Since it was a custom of those days to invariably and severely punish someone having incontinence while teaching a shogun, Iemochi realized this and hid the accident by mischievously pouring water on Yasukiyo, expressing that he would overlook the incident by saying, 'You have to attend at the court tomorrow as well.'

sen.j: その細やかな配慮に感激して泣いているのだと答えたという（安清の親戚だった戸川残花が「幕末小史」の中に記している）。
sen.e: It is said that he answered that he was crying because he was impressed by Iemochi's scrupulous attention (Zanka TOGAWA, a relative of Yasukiyo, wrote in 'Bakumatsu Shoshi' (Small History in the end of Edo Period).
sen.cmt: 「幕末小史」： 'Bakumatsu Shoshi' (Small History in the end of Edo Period) と訳しました。
sen.e: It is said that he answered that he was crying because he was impressed by Iemochi's scrupulous attention (Zanka TOGAWA, a relative of Yasukiyo, wrote in 'Bakumatsu Shoshi' (Small History in the end of Edo Period).

It is said that he answered that he was crying because he was impressed by Iemochi's scrupulous attention (Zanka TOGAWA, a relative of Yasukiyo, wrote in 'Bakumatsu Shoshi' (Small History in the end of Edo Period).

sen.j: 文久3年（1863年）4月、家茂は朝廷に命じられた攘夷実行への準備として、幕府の軍艦順動丸に乗って大坂視察を行っている。
sen.e: In April, 1863, Iemochi went over to Osaka by Jundo Maru Warship to prepare for carrying over an expulsion of foreigners ordered by the Imperial Court.
In April, 1863, Iemochi traveled to Osaka by a Jundo Maru Warship in preparation for carrying out an order of the Imperial Court to expel foreigners.
sen.cmt: fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: In April, 1863, Iemochi traveled to Osaka by a Jundo Maru Warship in preparation for carrying out an order of the Imperial Court to expel foreigners.

sen.j: この時順動丸を指揮していた勝海舟から軍艦の機能の説明を受け、非常に優れた理解力を示した。
sen.e: At this time, he was explained about functions of the warship by Kaishu KATSU who was taking control of the ship, and showed excellent understanding.
During this time, the commander named Kaishu KATSU explained to Iemochi the functions of the warship and Iemochi showed excellent understanding.
sen.cmt: rearranged sentence, changed subject and fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: During this time, the commander named Kaishu KATSU explained to Iemochi the functions of the warship and Iemochi showed excellent understanding.

sen.j: その折に勝から軍艦を動かせる人材の育成を直訴されると、即座に神戸海軍操練所の設置を命令した。
sen.e: On this occasion, Katsu directly asked him to train personnel who could operate a warship, and he immediately ordered to establish Kobe Navy Training Center.
On this occasion, Katsu directly asked him to train personnel who could operate warships and Iemochi immediately ordered the establishment of Kobe Navy Training Center.
sen.cmt: eliminated "a" before "warship"; warship > warships; eliminated comma after "warships"; he > Iemochi; ordered to establish > ordered the establishment of
sen.e: On this occasion, Katsu directly asked him to train personnel who could operate warships and Iemochi immediately ordered the establishment of Kobe Navy Training Center.

sen.j: さらに同年12月に上洛の際、勝の進言を容れて順動丸を使うことを決断した（その理由として前回の上洛において往路だった陸行では22日を要したのに対し、帰路順動丸を使った時にはわずか3日で江戸に帰れた事実がある。
sen.e: In addition, for the proceeding to the capital in December of the same year, he incorporated Katsu's advice and decided to use Jundo Maru (the reason is the fact that at the previous proceeding to the capital, it took them for 22 days to get to the capital by land, but it only took them for 3 days when they went back to Edo by Jundo Maru.

Additionally, Iemochi incorporated Katsu's advice for the procession to the capital in December of the same year, deciding to use Jundo Maru (the reason being that the previous procession to the capital by land took twenty-two days, but took only three days when they went back to Edo by Jundo Maru.
sen.cmt: fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: Additionally, Iemochi incorporated Katsu's advice for the procession to the capital in December of the same year, deciding to use Jundo Maru (the reason being that the previous procession to the capital by land took twenty-two days, but took only three days when they went back to Edo by Jundo Maru.

sen.j: そのことが勝への信頼感へつながったとする説がある）。
sen.e: It has been said that this contributed to a feeling of trust on Katsu.
It is said that this contributed to a feeling of trust for Katsu).
sen.cmt: fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: It is said that this contributed to a feeling of trust for Katsu).

sen.j: さらに航海の途中で海が荒れて船に酔う人が続出したため、側近から陸行への変更を奨められたが、この時「海上のことは軍艦奉行に任せよ」と厳命し、勝への変わらぬ信頼を表した。
sen.e: Furthermore, since more and more people got seasick because of stormy sea during the voyage, close associates recommended him for changing the plan to go by land, however, he strictly ordered to 'leave it to gunkan bugyo (the government's naval magistrate) in terms of issues on the sea' and expressed unchanged trust to Katsu.
sen.cmt: 陸行への変更を: 計画を陸行へ変更 という表現に補いました。
sen.e: Furthermore, although people were continuing to get seasick due to rough seas during the voyage and close associates recommended changing the plan to go by land, Iemochi strictly ordered to 'leave it to the gunkan bugyo (the government's naval magistrate) for issues on the sea' and expressed unchanged trust for Katsu.
sen.cmt: fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: Furthermore, although people were continuing to get seasick due to rough seas during the voyage and close associates recommended changing the plan to go by land, Iemochi strictly ordered to 'leave it to the gunkan bugyo (the government's naval magistrate) for issues on the sea' and expressed unchanged trust for Katsu.

sen.j: これらの信任に勝は感激し、家茂に対する生涯の忠誠を心中深く誓ったという。
sen.e: It is said that Katsu was greatly impressed with these confidences and he gave his loyalty to Iemochi from the bottom of his heart for the rest of his life.
It is said that Katsu was greatly impressed with the confidences bestowed upon him and gave his loyalty to Iemochi from the bottom of his heart for the rest of his life.
sen.cmt: with these confidences > with the confidences bestowed upon him; eliminated "he" before "gave";
sen.e: It is said that Katsu was greatly impressed with the confidences bestowed upon him and gave his loyalty to Iemochi from the bottom of his heart for the rest of his life.

sen.j: 家茂の死去した際絶望のあまり、日記に「徳川家、今日滅ぶ」と記したほどである。
sen.e: He even wrote in his diary as 'the Tokugawa family died down today' from his disappointment with Iemochi's death.
In his disappointment after Iemochi's death, Katsu was so upset that he wrote in his diary, 'Today, the Tokugawa family fell into ruin.'
sen.cmt: rearranged sentence, changed subject and fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: In his disappointment after Iemochi's death, Katsu was so upset that he wrote in his diary, 'Today, the Tokugawa family fell into ruin.'

sen.j: その後も勝は徳川家の保護と存続のため、気が合わなかった徳川慶喜の助命に奔走し、晩年に至るまで徳川家の存続と名誉回復に尽力し続けた。
sen.e: After that, Katsu continuously made efforts for continuance and rehabilitation of the Tokugawa family until his later years by struggling to save life of Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA, whom he didn't get along much with, to protect the Tokugawa family and make it last.

Even after Iemochi passed away, Katsu continuously made efforts toward the continuance and rehabilitation of the Tokugawa family until his later years by struggling to save the life of Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA, whom with he did not get along well, to protect the Tokugawa family and make it last.
sen.cmt: After that > Even after Iemochi passed away; made efforts for continuance > made efforts toward the continuance; fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: Even after Iemochi passed away, Katsu continuously made efforts toward the continuance and rehabilitation of the Tokugawa family until his later years by struggling to save the life of Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA, whom with he did not get along well, to protect the Tokugawa family and make it last.

sen.j: 晩年は家茂の名を聞いただけで、病弱な体で激動の時代に重責を背負わされた家茂の生涯に「お気の毒の人なりし」と言って目に涙を浮かべたという。
sen.e: It is said that in his later years, he teared saying 'I'm sorry for him' only by hearing his name thinking of the life of Iemochi who was gave burden in the age of upturn while he was sickly.

It is said that in his later years, tears would fall from his face upon hearing the mention of Iemochi, and he would say 'My heart bleeds for him,' thinking of his life with such a burden in a turbulent age with poor physical health.
sen.cmt: fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: It is said that in his later years, tears would fall from his face upon hearing the mention of Iemochi, and he would say 'My heart bleeds for him,' thinking of his life with such a burden in a turbulent age with poor physical health.

sen.j: 欧州における絹の産地として知られたフランス・イタリアでは、1850年代にノゼマと呼ばれる原生生物が原因とするカイコの伝染病が流行し、両国の養蚕業は壊滅状態になった。
sen.e: In France and Italy, known production areas of silk in Europe, silkworm infectious disease, which was caused by protist called Nosema, broke out in 1850's, and sericultural industry in both countries became destructive.

In France and Italy, known production areas of silk in Europe, silkworm infectious disease caused by the protist called Nosema broke out during the 1850's, devastating the sericultural industry in both countries.
sen.cmt: fixed grammar to have less commas and read more naturally
sen.e: In France and Italy, known production areas of silk in Europe, silkworm infectious disease caused by the protist called Nosema broke out during the 1850's, devastating the sericultural industry in both countries.

sen.j: これを知った家茂は、蚕の卵を農家から集めてナポレオン3世に寄贈した。
sen.e: When Iemochi heard the news, he collected silkworm eggs from farmers and donated them to Louis NAPOLEON.
When Iemochi heard of this news, he collected silkworm eggs from farmers and donated them to Louis NAPOLEON.
When Iemochi heard of this news, he collected silkworm eggs from farmers and donated them to Louis NAPOLEON.

sen.j: フランスではルイ・パスツールがジャン・アンリ・ファーブルの助言を元に、日本の蚕を研究して病気の原因を突き止めるとともに、生き残った蚕同士を掛け合わせて品種改良を行った。
sen.e: In France, Louis PASTEUR studied Japanese silkworm based on advices from Jean-Henri FABRE, and found out the cause of the disease and made breed improvement by breeding survived silkworms.
In France, Louis PASTEUR studied Japanese silkworms based on advice from Jean-Henri FABRE, figured out the cause of the disease and made improvements by breeding the surviving silkworms.
sen.cmt: advices > advice; and found out > figured out; made breed improvement > made improvements by breeding the; survived > surviving
sen.e: In France, Louis PASTEUR studied Japanese silkworms based on advice from Jean-Henri FABRE, figured out the cause of the disease and made improvements by breeding the surviving silkworms.

sen.j: ナポレオン3世は謝礼として慶応3年（1867年）に、幕府に対して軍馬の品種改良のためのアラビア馬26頭を贈呈した。
sen.e: In 1867, Louis NAPOLEON gifted 26 Arabian horses to bakufu for breed improvement of military horses as a remuneration.
In 1867, Louis NAPOLEON presented twenty-six Arabian horses to the bakufu for breeding improvements of their military horses as a gift.
sen.cmt: gifted > presented; 26 > twenty-six; added "the" before "bakufu"; breed > breeding; added "their" before "military"; remuneration > gift;
sen.e: In 1867, Louis NAPOLEON presented twenty-six Arabian horses to the bakufu for breeding improvements of their military horses as a gift.

sen.j: 飼育の伝習も同時に行われ、小金牧（千葉県松戸市）で大切に飼育される予定だったが、戊辰戦争で散り散りになった。
sen.e: A training for taking care of horses was also done at the same time, and it was planned to grow them carefully in Koganemaki (Matsudo City, Chiba Prefecture), they scattered around during the Boshin War.

Although training for taking care of the horses was also done at the same time, with plans to raise them carefully in Koganemaki (Matsudo City, Chiba Prefecture), the horses became scattered during the Boshin War.
sen.cmt: added "Although"; eliminated "A"; added "the" before "horses"; fixed grammar
sen.e: Although training for taking care of the horses was also done at the same time, with plans to raise them carefully in Koganemaki (Matsudo City, Chiba Prefecture), the horses became scattered during the Boshin War.
